factoid: Zakhár shouted that I should turn to the left.
Nicholas thought why turn to the left.
They were getting to the Melyukóvs'.
It was Melyukóvka.
Heaven only knows where we are going.
Heaven knows what is happening to us.
It is very strange and pleasant whatever it is.
Nicholas looked round in the sleigh.
The person with fine eyebrows and mustache said that his mustache and eyelashes are all white.
Nicholas thought this used to be Natásha.
Nicholas thought that was Madame Schoss.
Nicholas thought that the Circassian with the mustache he does not know.
Nicholas loved her.
Nicholas asked if he was cold.
They did not answer but began to laugh.
Dimmler shouted something that was probably funny.
Some voices answered, laughing.
There was a fairy forest with black moving shadows.
There was a glitter of diamonds.
There was a flight of marble steps.
There were silver roofs of fairy buildings.
There were shrill yells of some animals.
This is really Melyukóvka.
They drove heaven knows where and have come to Melyukóvka.
It really was Melyukóvka.
Maids and footmen with merry faces came running out to the porch carrying candles.
Someone in the porch asked who is it.
Some voices replied that the mummers were from the count's.
Pelagéya Danílovna Melyukóva is a broadly built energetic woman wearing spectacles.
Pelagéya Danílovna Melyukóva sat in the drawing room in a loose dress.
Pelagéya Danílovna Melyukóva was surrounded by her daughters.
Pelagéya Danílovna Melyukóva was trying to keep her daughters from feeling dull.
The daughters quietly dropped melted wax into snow.
The daughters looked at the shadows the wax figures would throw on the wall.
They heard the steps and voices of new arrivals in the vestibule.
Hussars, ladies, witches, clowns, and bears came into the ballroom.
The clown Dimmler and the lady Nicholas started a dance.
The mummers covered their faces and disguised their voices.
The mummers bowed to the hostess.
The mummers arranged themselves about the room.
The hostess was Pelagéya Danílovna Melyukóva.
The mummers were from the count's.
Natásha was the young Melyukóvs' favorite.
Natásha disappeared with them into the back rooms.
The back rooms had a cork and various dressing gowns and male garments.
The footman received the dressing gowns from bare girlish arms from behind the door.
Ten minutes later all the young Melyukóvs joined the mummers.
Pelagéya Danílovna gave orders to clear the rooms for the visitors.
Pelagéya Danílovna arranged refreshments for the gentry and the serfs.
Pelagéya Danílovna went about among the mummers without removing her spectacles.
Pelagéya Danílovna peered into their faces with a suppressed smile.
Pelagéya Danílovna failed to recognize any of the mummers.
Pelagéya Danílovna did not even recognize her own daughters.
Pelagéya Danílovna did not even recognize her late husband's dressing gowns and uniforms.
Pelagéya Danílovna asked her governess who is this.
Pelagéya Danílovna peered into the face of her own daughter dressed up as a Kazán-Tartar.
Pelagéya Danílovna supposed it was one of the Rostóvs.
Pelagéya Danílovna asked Natásha what regiment the Hussar served in.
Pelagéya Danílovna ordered the butler to hand some fruit jelly to the Turk.
The butler handed things round.
The butler's action was not forbidden by his law.
